physical_examinations.relevant_findings: The proband presented with left subcostal pain, mucosal hyperemia, and friability on initial gastroscopy, followed by anorexia, weight loss, and abdominal bloating six weeks later.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Initially presented with mucosal hyperemia and friability, but later revealed metastatic signet-ring-cell carcinoma, indicating progression to a more severe condition.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Multiple sections taken from the stomach during gastrectomy were histologically normal, indicating the absence of lesions at the time of surgery.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Microscopic foci of intramucosal diffuse carcinoma were identified post-surgery, suggesting development of cancer that was not detected prior.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Subject IV-1 underwent elective gastrectomy, with superficial infiltrates of malignant signet-ring cells found in 65 out of 140 tissue blocks.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Foci of cancer representing less than 2% of the gastric mucosa were found post-treatment, indicating the emergence of early diffuse gastric cancer.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Gastrectomy specimen appeared grossly normal but had early diffuse gastric cancer with infiltrates of signet-ring cells.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Gastrectomy was performed as a prophylactic measure, finding malignant lesions that were not identified during prior examinations.
